title.narrative: 2016 Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund - Humanitarian Financing Unit (HFU)

description.narrative:
The Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund (the Fund) was established in early 2014 and operates within the parameters of the annual Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP), with three main objectives to support projects of humanitarian partners (non-governmental organizations (NGOs), UN Agencies and IOM) to address the most pressing evidence-based needs in accordance with humanitarian principles, to improve the relevance of humanitarian response, and to strengthen coordination and leadership through the Humanitarian Coordinator (HC) and the Cluster System.
The project will be implemented by OCHA’s Humanitarian Financing Unit (HFU), the Fund’s managing agent ensuring effective and efficient management of the Fund with activities lasting throughout 2016, in compliance with the minimum requirements described in the operational modalities of the CBPF Global Guidelines and Operational Manual.
Contributing to improved coordination, response and targeting of humanitarian activities, the HFU will work in a coherent and strategic fashion with the humanitarian community, clusters, UN lead agencies, donors, the Risk Management Unit, as well as the HCT and other stakeholders in country and at headquarters. The Fund’s allocation strategies will be developed in coordination with the Humanitarian Country Team (HCT) and Strategic Coordination Unit (SCU) to ensure that projects contribute to the strategic priorities outlined in the HRP, as endorsed by the Fund’s Advisory Board and approved by the HC.
The HFU’s administration of the Accountability Framework for a robust eligibility process, monitoring and reporting requirements, and audit system will allow for a high level of oversight, information collection and analysis to assess the performance of partners and to feed into future decision-making. In addition, the HFU will be accountable to its beneficiaries through timely feedback from user groups (HCT, NGO forums, Advisory Board).
Finally, the sensitization of the Fund’s processes and impact to current and interested stakeholders will sustain strong support and a significant number of partners and donors to address humanitarian needs in Afghanistan.
